channel.title: [Developement]Landscape Editor
channel.description:
Hello, I'm working on a landscape editor, and I'd like your opinion of it, as well as any suggestions you might have.
This is the current GUI:
[img]http://filesmelt.com/downloader/lsEditor.PNG[/img]
Now, I know, that doesn't look this much; And it isn't, the GUI contains but one component, a JPanel, a thread prints the current state of the currently selected sector at 45 FPS.
What I've got so far: The landscape file is loaded from the .jar files directory on startup. All sectors are loaded into an array on startup. Switch sectors with the arrow keys. Click/drag mouse to paint tiles.
What I'm planning: Ctrl+Z to undo changes to a sector. Save on close, overwriting the old landscape file.(I might create a file dialog box to save the file instead.) Parsing XML to load object positions. Flood painting tiles. Drawing shapes by dragging the mouse.(Rectangles/Squares/Circles) Drawing walls. Adding NPCs/Objects/Item spawns with a tool. Saving.(Didn't feel like doing it tonight, I'll do it when I get up.)
I can't think of anything else right now, I'm open to suggestions. I'll be releasing the program once I'm done with it, along with the source code.

item.title: [Developement]Landscape Editor
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

[quote=“Faggington, post:4, topic:299229”][quote author=xEnt link=topic=395569.msg2938767#msg2938767 date=1251733453]
you could always download the community landscape editor, decompile or get the source from svn, mod it then release, save you a lot of time. but gl
[/quote]
Thanks.
I started off with that source, and I ended up editing it quite a bit, but I decided to start from scratch after realizing that I wasn’t learning as much about the landscape as I was hoping to.

I’ve got one question;
Each sector contains 23040 bytes, 10 bytes per tile; I’m wondering what some of those bytes are used for, in particular the “shape” and “overlay” bytes.[/quote]
it’s been awhile since i have used that landscape editor, there should not be a shape byte, overlay is a byte of the types of overlays on the tile. For example inside draynor bank you’d have gray tiles, under that is actually grass (texture) and an overlay is the wooden look, water, lava, gray path etc.
